name: TOI-125
scenarioDescription:
The TOI-125 Exoplanetary System


Overview

TOI-125 is a star with 0.86 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.85 times its radius. It is located 363.34 light years away from the solar system and is estimated to be 6.8 billion years old, as compared to the Sun which is roughly 4.6 billion years old.

TOI-125 is known to have 3 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the TOI-125 system


TOI-125 b

TOI-125 b was discovered by the Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite (TESS) observatory using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.05 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of TOI-125 b is 9.50502 times the mass of Earth. The radius of TOI-125 b is 2.726 that of Earth. At 9.50502 Earth masses, TOI-125 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.


TOI-125 c

TOI-125 c was discovered by the Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite (TESS) observatory using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.08 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of TOI-125 c is 6.63348 times the mass of Earth. The radius of TOI-125 c is 2.759 that of Earth. At 6.63348 Earth masses, TOI-125 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.


TOI-125 d

TOI-125 d was discovered by the Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite (TESS) observatory using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.14 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of TOI-125 d is 13.60722 times the mass of Earth. The radius of TOI-125 d is 2.93 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, TOI-125 d is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system TOI-125, which contains 3 planets and was discovered by Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite (TESS).
